# Overview 
This is the analysis of white matter dsi studio connectometry for Maze and Loop 

# <span style="color: darkblue;">Methods </span> 
##### **Participants** 
* Total number of scans = 120 (males and females )
  * Total scans used in analysis= 118 
  *Exclude subs 329 and 372 from analyses
        
##### **Scan parameters** 
* Locations from UCSB and UCI

##### **QSIprep** 
* Version used: 0.16.0RC3
* The following parameters were used
  * dwi_denoise_window **5** 
  * hmc_model **3dSHORE** 
  * hmc-transform **Rigid** 
  * shoreline_iters **2**

### **DSI Studio**
*Version and tags used 
  * **chen-2022-07-31**
A diffusion spectrum imaging scheme was used, and a total of 128 diffusion sampling were acquired. The maximum b-value was 4990 s/mm². The in-plane resolution was 1.8 mm. The slice thickness was 1.8 mm. The accuracy of b-table orientation was examined by comparing fiber orientations with those of a population-averaged template (Yeh et al. Neuroimage, 2018). The b-table was flipped by .012fy. The diffusion data were reconstructed in the MNI space using q-space diffeomorphic reconstruction (Yeh et al., Neuroimage, 58(1):91-9, 2011) to obtain the spin distribution function (Yeh et al., IEEE TMI, ;29(9):1626-35, 2010).  A diffusion sampling length ratio of 1.25 was used. The output resolution in diffeomorphic reconstruction was 1.8 mm isotropic. The tensor metrics were calculated using DWI with b-value lower than 1750 s/mm². The quantitative anisotropy was extracted as the local connectome fingerprint (LCF, Yeh et al. PLoS Comput Biol 12(11): e1005203) and used in the connectometry analysis.</p>
<h4>Connectometry analysis</h4>
<p>
Diffusion MRI connectometry (Yeh et al. NeuroImage 125 (2016): 162-171) was used to derive the correlational tractography that has QA, MD, AD, and RD correlated with Maze Accuracy and Loop variables. A nonparametric Spearman partial correlation was used to derive the correlation, and the effect of sex, age_scan_years, and repo_status was removed using a multiple regression model. The total number of subjects varied on analysis (See Analyses and Final sample sizes above). A T-score threshold of 2.5 was assigned and tracked using a deterministic fiber tracking algorithm (Yeh et al. PLoS ONE 8(11): e80713, 2013) to obtain correlational tractography. A seeding region was placed at whole brain (39,49,29) .
 The tracks were filtered by topology-informed pruning (Yeh et al. Neurotherapeutics, 16(1), 52-58, 2019) with 4 iteration(s). A length threshold of 25 voxel distance was used to select tracks. To estimate the false discovery rate, a total of 4000 randomized permutations were applied to the group label to obtain the null distribution of the track length.</p>


###### **Parameters** 
* T-threshold = 2.5
* Length = 25
* Permutation = 4,000
* pruning 4
* non normalized QA

# <span style="color: darkorange;"> Maze Accuracy </span>  {.tabset .tabset-dropdown}  

#### <span style="color: darkgreen;"> Summary</span>  {.tabset}
A total of 82 diffusion MRI scans were included in the connectometry database. For the connectometry analysis, age, sex and repo status were listed as covariates. All subjects displayed positive and negative correlations between tracts with QA and Maze accuracy.Teacts in the fornix with MD and RD displayed positive relationships with Maze accuracy. AD displayed a negative relationship between tracts in the fornix and maze accuracy. All together the results suggest that increased diffusion (Md and RD) are associated with increased performance in scores in midlife participants and these associations are found in regions associated with spatial navigation. When split by sex, Men displayed a negative association between maze performance and a majority of tracts in the corpus callosum with QA. For AD, RD, and MD, men displayed significant positive relationships between performance. Altogether it suggests that better maze accuracy is associated with increased diffusion in midlife men.  Women displayed the opposite, tracts in the fornix with QA were positively associated with performance while tracts in the fornix, cingulum, and cerebellum  and  with AD,RD, and MD were negatively associated with performance. Suggesting that more specific diffusion is associated with better maze accuracy. Next, Menopause stages were analyzed separately. Pre menopausal women displayed both positive and negative correlations with QA while tracts with AD,RD and MD displayed negative relationships. Peri menopausal women displayed positive associations in tracts with QA, MD, RD, and AD and performance. This suggests that in peri menopasual women, maze accuracy is associated with increased diffusion in tracts on the fornix, cerebellum, and cingulum. Post menopausal women displayed both positive and negative associations between acc and QA. Post menopausal women displayed positive and negative assocoations with QA< MD, RD, and AD and maze accuracy. A majority of tracts in the fornix with AD,MD, and RD were positively associated with maze accuracy

## QA {.tabset}

### Summary of results 
There were both positive and negative correlations between QA and maze performance when all subjects were included in the analysis. When men were analyzed separately, men displayed more negatively associated correlations between QA and maze performance. Women displayed tracts with predominantly positive correlations between QA and performance. When split by menopause stagge, Pre and post displayed both positive and negative correlations while peri displayed only positive correlations with performance.

## MD {.tabset}
### Summary of results 
DSI was run on all subjects, with sex and age listed as covariates. There were positive correlations between MD values in the Fornix (L&R) and performance. Using a sex stratified apporoach we viewed the relationship between white matter and performance in men and women separately. Men, displayed a majortiy of positive correlations between tracts with MD and accuracy. Specifically in regions associated with navigation such as the fornix (L & R).  Women, displayed a majortiy of negative correlations between tracts with MD and accuracy. Specifically in regions associated with navigation such as the fornix (L & R), and cerebelllum. We then investigated the relationship of white matter and performance when splitting by menopause stage. Pre menopause women displayed a majortiy of negative correlations between tracts with MD and accuracy in the fornix(L&R) and corpus callosum. Peri menopause women displayed a majority of positive correlations between tracts with MD and accuracy in the fornix(L&R) cerebellum and cingulum. Post Menopause displayed both positive and negative relationships between MD and  performance. The majority of tracts with positive correlations were in the fornix, while a majority of the negative correlations were found in tracts in the parietal cortex and cerebellum.

### Summary of results 
Only fornix was negatively associated with performance when all subejcts were analyzed. Fornix and thalamic raditions were positively associated with accuracy.Women displayed negative relationships with tracts int he fornix and cingulum and maze acc. Women in the pre menopasual groups showed tracts were negatively correlated with acc in fornix ,and  corpus callosum. Peri menopausal women showed that a majority of tracts in the fornix, cingulum, and cerebellum were positively associated with Acc. Post menopasual women showed positive tracts in the fornix and negative tracts in the cerbebellum.

### Summary of results 
QA values in several tracts were negatively correlated with Loop Position Error performance in a circle with a 3 m radius. When men and women were analyzed separately, there were different relationships observed. The majority of tracts in men were positively correlated with Position Error and QA values.Suggesting that better QA and white matter integrity is associated with increased Position error. The majority of tracts in women were negatively correlated with QA values and Position error, with a few that were positive. This suggests that in women, white matter integrity is associated with lower position error scores. When splitting by meno pause stage, Pre menopausal women displayed both negative and positive relationships between QA and position error. Peri menopausal women displayed negative correlations between QA and position error. .

### Summary of Results 
For all subjects, Degree error was correlated with QA values with age and sex marked as covariates. Tracts with QA values were both positively and negatively correlated with DE performance. When analyzed by sex, Men displayed tracts that were significantly negatively correlated with DE, DSI found no tracts positively correlated with DE (FDR=1.00). DSI  studio found that tracts with QA in women displayed both positive and negative associations with DE performance. Women were further analyzed by menopause stage. Pre-menopause women displayed positive and negative relationships between tracts with QA and DE performance. DSI sutdio found that peri-menopause women displayed significant negative correlations between tracts with QA and DE and there were not significant positive correlations ( FDR= 0.7516098). Women in post menopause displayed no significant positive or negtive correlations (FDR= 1.000, 0.354664, respectively). When peri and post menopause women were grouped together, tracts with QA were positively and negatively correlated with DE performance

Tracts with MD were positively correlated with DE performance when all subjects were analyzed. In men, there were no significantly correlated tracts associated with DE performance. In women, tracts with MD were positively associated with DE performance. Pre-menopause women displayed MD tracts with significantly positively correlations to DE.
